column1: Dyersburg is a city and the county seat of Dyer County
column3: in the United States. It is located in northwest Tennessee
column4: 79 miles (127 km) northeast of Memphis on the Forked Deer River. The population was 17

column1: The lands that make up Dyersburg once belonged to the Chickasaw people. The final treaty by which they relinquished all of West Tennessee was signed in 1818.
The first European settlers began to arrive in the area around 1819. In 1823
column2: the Tennessee General Assembly passed an act to establish two new counties immediately west of the Tennessee River
column3: Dyer County being one of them. John McIver and Joel H. Dyer donated 60 acres (240
column4: 000 m2) for the new county seat
column6: at a central location within the county known as "McIver's Bluff". In 1825
column7: Dyer surveyed the town site into 86 lots. The first courthouse was built on the square in 1827. The current Classical Revival-style courthouse
column9: centers a downtown historic district listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Situated as the hub of steamboat navigation on the Forked Deer River
column2: Dyersburg grew as a river town
column3: especially once the Grey Eagle made the first successful steamboat trip in 1836. The county's first industrial boom dates to 1879
column4: when the steamboat Alf Stevens shipped timber from A. M. Stevens Lumber Company of Dyersburg to St. Louis
column5: Missouri markets. The Stevens company established a large sawmill in 1880 and opened a planing mill in 1885. The Bank of Dyersburg opened in 1880
column8: began operations in 1881.The arrival of the Newport News and Mississippi Valley Railroad in 1884 further expanded market possibilities; a branch line
column10: soon linked the county seat to Tiptonville. The new railroad links encouraged the creation of new industries and businesses. In 1884
column12: investors established the Dyersburg Oil Company
column13: a cottonseed factory. This company remained locally important through the 20th century.

column2: a number of skirmishes occurred in the Dyersburg area resulting in Union victories. On August 7
column4: about 50 men of the 6th Illinois Cavalry Regiment attacked a group of Confederates about 5 miles east of Dyersburg.  In a report by Brigadier General Grenville M. Dodge
column5: he wrote the Confederates who escaped left without their clothes
column7: or horses and said that "they killed some 25 to 30 [Confederates]
column9: and a large number of guns & arms." Dodge also recommended burning the county as "They pay no attention to the oath
column10: feed and guide the rebels." He reported they were assisted in routing the Confederates by "two Negros" and that "No white man had the pluck to do it." On August 18
column12: the 6th Illinois Cavalry Regiment attacked a small band of Confederates on the Obion River six miles from Dyersburg taking all their horses
column16: Union forces under the command of Colonel Oliver Wood of the 22nd Ohio Infantry Regiment "completely routed them [Confederates]
column20: when the rebels broke and fled in every direction." Nathan Bedford Forrest and Robert V. Richardson occupied Dyersburg in August 1863
column21: until they retreated upon the arrival of Colonel Edward Hatch in the area.

column2: Dyersburg emerged as a regional railroad hub as it became the junction point for three different lines
column3: led by the Illinois Central Railroad.
a 24-year-old black farmhand named Lation (or Ligon) Scott was brutally lynched by a white mob before a crowd of thousands.  Over the course of several hours
column4: Scott was publicly tortured. He was chained to a post in an empty lot adjacent to the town's court square. Torturers burned out his eyes with red-hot irons. When he cried out in pain
column5: a red-hot poker was rammed down his esophagus. He was then castrated
column6: and more hot irons placed on his feet
column8: and body until "a hideous stench of burning flesh filled the Sabbath air". After being tortured
column9: Scott was slowly burned at the stake. Scott's torture and murder occurred over a three and a half hour period. No one was prosecuted for the lynching. Author Margaret Vandiver wrote in "Lethal Punishment: Lynchings and Legal Executions in the South"
column10: “The lynching of Lation Scott was the most ghastly of all those I researched.”In 1942
column11: Dyersburg Army Air Base was established by the War Department to facilitate and support military bomber training. Following the end of World War II
column12: the base was decommissioned in 1946. A museum is currently located at the site of the former air base.On March 5
column14: a Piper Comanche plane carrying country singers Patsy Cline
column17: and Cline's manager/pilot Randy Hughes stopped to refuel in Dyersburg. The plane crashed around 20 minutes later in inclement weather near Camden

column3: Harold Kilpatrick Jr. took 15 people hostage in a classroom at Dyersburg State Community College. Kilpatrick was killed following a nine-hour standoff with police.

column2: multiple peaceful demonstrations were held in downtown Dyersburg. These protests focused on systemic racism and police brutality. At one of the protests a speech was given about Lation Scott
column3: a man who was brutally lynched in front of a crowd of thousands in the same court square over a hundred years prior.

column1: Dyersburg is located in central Dyer County at 36°2′22″N 89°22′58″W (36.039440
column2: -89.382766). According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 17.5 square miles (45.2 km2)
column4: of which 17.3 square miles (44.9 km2) is land and 0.1 square miles (0.3 km2)
column6: is water.Dyersburg is located on the Forked Deer River and is 13 miles from the Mississippi River.

column1: The city's proximity to the New Madrid Seismic Zone places it at risk for future earthquakes. USGS data shows an 18.28% chance of a major earthquake within 31 miles (50 km) of Dyersburg within the next 50 years. The largest earthquake within 30 miles (48 km) of Dyersburg was a 4.0-magnitude event in 2005.

column2: Dyersburg was home to a Minor League Baseball team known as the Dyersburg Forked Deers (1923–1924) and Dyersburg Deers (1925). They won the Kentucky–Illinois–Tennessee League championship in 1923 and 1924.

column1: West Tennessee Healthcare Dyersburg Hospital is a Joint Commission accredited hospital. The medical center has 225 beds. Originally built as Parkview Hospital in 1956
column2: the hospital has changed stewardship multiple times since its inception.
